org.jeo.raster

Class DataBuffer<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jeo.raster.DataBuffer<T>

  • public abstract class DataBuffer<T>
extends Object
    Wrapper around a ByteBuffer that abstracts away data type of values put into the buffer.

    The buffer wrapper maintains a native datatype(). Values returned from get() are of this native type. Values of any type may be put into the buffer via put(Object)

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public static DataBuffer create(ByteBuffer buffer,
                DataType datatype)
        Creates a new wrapper from a byte buffer and specified datatype.

      • create

        public static DataBuffer create(int size,
                DataType datatype)
        Creates a new wrapper by allocating a new buffer of the specified size and type.

      • resample

        public static <T> DataBuffer<T> resample(DataBuffer<T> buffer,
                         Dimension from,
                         Dimension to)
        Resamples the buffer using nearest neighbour interpolation.

        Resampling works in two dimensions and requires the image dimensions of this buffer and the buffer being resampled to.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Buffer type.
        Parameters:
        buffer - The buffer to resample.
        from - The image dimensions of this buffer.
        to - The image dimensions of the resampled buffer.
        Returns:
        The resampled buffer.

      • buffer

        public ByteBuffer buffer()
        The underlying byte buffer.

      • get

        public abstract T get()
        Retrieves the value of type datatype() from the current position.

        This method does no bounds checking to ensure the current position is valid.

      • get

        public T get(int i)
        Retrieves the value of type datatype() at the specified position.

        The position i is relative to the datatype size. For example in a buffer of type DataType.INT a position of 10 refers to the 10th integer, not the 10th byte. In this case it would map to an underlying position of 10*4 = 40.

        This method does no bounds checking to ensure the index is valid.

      • put

        public DataBuffer<T> put(Object val)
        Puts data into the buffer at the current position.

        The value val must be one of the well known primitive wrapper types (other than Boolean).

        This method does no bounds checking to ensure the current position is valid.

      • put

        public DataBuffer<T> put(int i,
                T val)
        Puts data into the buffer at the specified position.

        The position i is relative to the datatype size. For example in a buffer of type DataType.INT a position of 10 refers to the 10th integer, not the 10th byte. In this case it would map to an underlying position of 10*4 = 40.

        The value val must be one of the well known primitive wrapper types (other than Boolean).

        This method does no bounds checking to ensure the index is valid.

      • flip

        public DataBuffer<T> flip()
        Flips the buffer.
        See Also:
        java.nio.Buffer#flip()}

      • rewind

        public DataBuffer<T> rewind()
        Rewinds the buffer.

        This method resets the word index to 0 in addition to resetting the buffer position.

        See Also:
        java.nio.Buffer#rewind()}

      • word

        public DataBuffer<T> word()
        Advances the word index to the next value and sets the buffer position to the same value.

        This method is used to keep the buffer aligned at "word boundaries" in cases where data types of different sizes are being put into the buffer.

      • size

        public int size()
        The size of the buffer, relative to the datatype().

        For data types other than DataType.BYTE this is not the same as buffer().capacity(). Rather it is calculated as: 

              buffer().capacity()/datatype().size()

      • datatype

        public DataType datatype()
        The data type of the buffer.
